questions.text: Original DNA sequence: 5'-ATG GCA TCG GAA UAC-3'. Mutated sequence: 5'-ATG GCA TCG GAA UAA-3'. Identify the mutation.
questions.correct_answer: B. Nonsense mutation
questions.explanation:
Based on the Effects on Amino acid sequence

Silent Mutation
(Option C ruled out)

Missense Mutation
(Option D ruled out)

Nonsense Mutation
(Option B)
  • Mutation may change the codon for one amino acid to a synonym for the same amino acid.
  • It has no effect on the phenotype.
  • Degeneracy of the code.
  • Different amino acid is incorporated due to change in the nucleotide sequence.
  • It can be acceptable, partially acceptable, and unacceptable .
  • Codon for an amino acid is mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UAG) causing premature termination of translation.

questions.text: Identify the type of mutation illustrated in the following DNA sequences? Starting sequence: Mutated sequence:
questions.correct_answer: A. Point mutation
questions.explanation:
Based on the Effects on Nucleotide sequence

Point mutation (Option A)

Frameshift mutation (Option B ruled out)

Substitution of one nucleotide by another.

  • Transition: Purine is replaced by a purine and a pyrimidine is replaced by a pyrimidine.
  • Transversion: Purine is replaced by a pyrimidine and vice versa.

Deletion (Option C ruled out) or insertion (Option D ruled out) of nucleotides leading to altered reading frame in the mRNA.

questions.text: Which technique is commonly used for DNA sequencing to identify mutations by determining the precise order of nucleotides in a DNA sample?
questions.correct_answer: C. Sanger technique
questions.explanation:
Methods

Uses

Advantages/ disadvantages

Cytogenetics

Karyotype

Detecting numerical and gross structural aberrations
  • Low-resolution
  • Time consuming

FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) (Option A ruled out)

 Detects copy number variations, structural alterations like translocations and microdeletion Detects Limitation: Can be used only for known defects

CGH (Comparative genomic hybridization)

Detects copy number variations of genetic material

Can be used to detect unknown chromosomal aberrations

Used only for losses and gains

Molecular

RFLP (Restriction fragment length polymorphism)

Restriction fragments are separated by electrophoresis

Requires availability of enzyme with restriction site at the mutation site

DNA Sequencing

Sanger technique (Option C) is the most widely used.

Directly determines the nucleotide sequence of a DNA fragment.

Detects point mutations, small deletions and insertions.

DNA microarray

Microscopic DNA spots attached to a solid surface

Multiple mutations can be detected.

ARMS PCR ( Amplification refractory mutation system)

Allele-specific amplification of mutant and normal allele, determination of the genotype of an individual
  • Highly sensitive
  • May increase time and costs

Multiplex PCR (Polymerase chain reaction)

Amplification of more than one target simultaneously
  • Reduces time and labour requirements
  • Lower sensitivity and specificity

Real-time PCR

Amplification, detection, and quantification of target
  • Increased specificity
  • Eliminates post-amplification analyses
  • More expensive

MLPA (Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification) (Option B ruled out)

Deletions and duplications
  • Identifies very small single gene aberrations (50-70 nt)

DGGE (Denaturing Gradient Gel Electrophoresis)

Based on migration within gradient gel electrophoresis

Detects close to 100% of point mutations

SSCP (Single Strand Conformational Polymorphism) (Option D ruled out)

Based on migration of single-stranded conformation on gel electrophoresis

 

Detects about 80–90% of point mutations

Hetero-duplex analysis

Based on homoduplices and heteroduplices motilities in gel electrophoresis

Detects nearly 80% of mutations

OLA (Oligonucleotide ligation assay)

It is based on the ligation of two flanked primers annealed with target sequences

Detects all base exchanges

PTT (Protein truncation test)

It is based on a combination of PCR, transcription, and translation
  • Detects translation-terminating mutations.
  • Missense mutations are not detected.

questions.text: Which class of antibiotics inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosomal A site?
questions.correct_answer: A. Tetracyclines
questions.explanation:
Inhibitors of Protein Synthesis

Mechanism of action
Reversible Inhibitors in Bacteria (bacteriostatic)

Tetracyclines (Option A)
  • Binds to the 30S ribosome of bacteria and inhibit attachment of aminoacyl tRNA to the A site.

Chloramphenicol (Option B ruled out)
  • Inhibits the peptidyl transferase activity of bacterial ribosomes
Erythromycin (macrolides) (Option C ruled out) and clindamycin
  • Inhibits the translocation process.
Irreversible Inhibitors in Bacteria (bactericidal)

Aminoglycoside
  • Bind to 30S subunit of bacterial ribosomes. Misreading of mRNA.
  • Inhibit the initiation complex formation and totally inhibit protein synthesis.
Inhibitors of Protein Synthesis in Mammals

Puromycin (Option D ruled out)
  • Analogue of tyrosine tRNA and attaches to the “A” site of the ribosome causing premature termination.

Cycloheximide
  • Inhibits peptidyl transferase in 60S subunit

Diphtheria toxin
  • Inactivation of EF-2 by attachment of ADP to EF-2

questions.text: What is the total number of ATPs required for activating amino acids by aminoacyl tRNA synthetase?
questions.explanation:
Steps

Number of ATPs needed

Activating amino acids by aminoacyl tRNA synthetase (Option B)

2

Activating of eEF1 (A attaches amino acyl tRNA to A site)

1

Activating eEF2 (helps in translocation of ribosomes)

1

Total

4

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about aminoacyl tRNA?

options.label: A
options.text: Attaches to the A site of 60s ribosomes

questions.correct_answer: A. Attaches to the A site of 60s ribosomes
questions.explanation:
Initiation methionine tRNA (imet-tRNA)

Aminoacyl tRNA (aa-tRNA)

Involved in the initiation of translation.

Involved in the elongation step of translation.

Guided by eIF2C (Option C ruled out)

Guided by eEF1A

 

Attaches to the P site of 60s ribosome

Attaches to the A site of 60s ribosome (Option A)

Utilises 3 high energy phosphates for each peptide bond formation (Option B ruled out)

Utilises 4 high energy phosphates for each peptide bond formation

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT TRUE regarding the initiation of translation?

options.label: A
options.text: eIF3 and 1A stabilize 60s ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 40s.

options.label: B
options.text: Methionine tRNA scans mRNA to identify the initiation AUG codon

options.label: C
options.text: ATP dependent helicase eIF4A/4B breaks hydrogen bonds to remove the hairpin loops

options.label: D
options.text: Association of mRNA with the 43S preinitiation complex forms the 48S initiation complex

questions.correct_answer: A. eIF3 and 1A stabilize 60s ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 40s.

questions.text: Match the following phases of translation (Column A) with the events involved (Column B). Column A Column B 1. Elongation a. RF1 binds with RF3 and GTP 2. Initiation b. Binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome's A site 3. Termination c. Methionine tRNA scans mRNA for AUG codon
questions.explanation:
Phases of translation

Key events

Initiation
  • Dissociation of 80s ribosome into 60s and 40s, and stabilized by various initiation factors.
  • Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex: The 40S ribosomal subunit, in association with initiation factors, binds to the initiator tRNA (carrying methionine in eukaryotes or formyl-methionine in prokaryotes)forming the 43S preinitiation complex.
  • Formation of 48S initiation complex: The 43S complex binds to the 5' end of the mRNA, and scans for start codon which upon recognition, the 48S initiation complex is formed.
  • Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex: Binding of the 60S ribosomal subunit to the 48S initiation. The met-tRNA on the P site of the ribosome is ready for the elongation cycle.

Elongation
  • Binding of Aminoacyl-tRNA to the A Site
  • Peptide Bond Formation
  • Elongation factor 2 (EF2) binds to and displaces the peptidyl tRNA from the A site to the P site

Termination
  • Ribosome reaches the terminator codon sequence (UAA, UAG or UGA)
  • Releasing factor(RF1), (RF3) and GTP complex promotes hydrolysis releasing the protein and the tRNA from the P site.

questions.text: Sickle cell anaemia is suspected in a 25-year-old patient who presents with episodes of abdominal pain and fatigue. Genetic analysis reveals GAG in the 6th position is replaced with GTG. Which type of mutation here results in haemoglobin that is still functional but altered?
questions.correct_answer: B. Partially acceptable mutation
questions.explanation:
Based on the Effects on the function of protein

Acceptable mutation: (Option C ruled out)

Partially acceptable mutation: (Option B)

Unacceptable mutation: (Option A ruled out)

Change in the nucleotide sequence causes alteration in the amino sequence that does not affect the functioning of the protein.

Example: Hb Sydney

Change in the nucleotide sequence causing alteration in the amino sequence that affects the functioning of the protein but it is not immediately life-threatening.

Example: HbS - GAG is replaced by GTG which replaces the glutamic acid to valine.

Change in the nucleotide sequence causes alteration in the amino sequence that affects the functioning of the protein so extensively that it is immediately life-threatening.

Example: Congenital methemoglobinemia (HbM) - Histidine (CAU) is replaced with tyrosine (UAU) in alpha-chain.

questions.text: A DNA sequence originally reads 5'-ATG GCA TCG TAC-3'. After a mutation, it reads 5'-ATG GCT CGT AC-3'. Identify the mutation that has occured?
questions.correct_answer: A. Frameshift mutation
questions.explanation:
Based on the Effects on Nucleotide sequence

Point mutation (Option B ruled out)

Frameshift mutation (Option A)

Substitution of one nucleotide by another.

  • Transition (Option C ruled out): A purine is replaced by a purine, and a pyrimidine is replaced by a pyrimidine.
  • Transversion: Purine is replaced by a pyrimidine and vice versa.

Deletion (Option A ruled out) or insertion (Option D ruled out) of nucleotides leads to an altered reading frame in the mRNA.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately reflects a difference between DNA and RNA, considering their roles in genetic information processing and stability?

options.label: A
options.text: RNA's 2'-hydroxyl group enhances its stability compared to DNA.

options.label: B
options.text: RNA polymerases need a primer; DNA polymerases do not.

options.label: C
options.text: RNA forms complex structures; DNA remains a double helix

options.label: D
options.text: DNA degrades more rapidly than RNA due to the presence of a 2'-hydroxyl group.

questions.correct_answer: C. RNA forms complex structures; DNA remains a double helix
questions.explanation:
Aspect

DNA

RNA

Sugar

Deoxyribose (lacks 2' hydroxyl group) (Option D ruled out)

Ribose (has 2' hydroxyl group)

Bases

Adenine (A), Guanine (G), Cytosine (C), Thymine (T)

Adenine (A), Guanine (G), Cytosine (C), Uracil (U)

Structure

Double-stranded helix, antiparallel strands, complementary base pairing (A-T, G-C)

DNA follows both Chargaff rule of base pairing and Watson and Crick base pairing rule.

Single-stranded, can fold into complex structures with intrachain base pairing (A-U, G-C) (Option C)
Do not follow Chargaff's Rule of Base Pairing.

Watson and Crick Base pairing rule is followed here.

Function

Stores genetic information

Various roles in gene expression:

Messenger RNA (mRNA) -

Carries genetic information from DNA to ribosomes for protein synthesis

Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) -

Major component of ribosomes, involved in protein synthesis

Transfer RNA (tRNA) -

Transports amino acids to ribosomes during protein synthesis

Stability

More stable due to lack of 2'-hydroxyl group B (Option A ruled out)

Less stable, more susceptible to hydrolysis

Degradation Susceptibility

Less prone to degradation, stable over generations

More prone to degradation, shorter lifespan, important for regulating gene expression

Synthesis Primer Requirement

Requires RNA primer for initiation
(Option B ruled out)

Can initiate synthesis de novo, no primer needed

Proofreading and Fidelity

High fidelity with 3' to 5' exonuclease activity for proofreading

Higher error rate but can backtrack and cleave incorrect nucleotides.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding codons? A, G, T, C are RNA nucleotides A, G, T, C are DNA nucleotides A, G, U, C are RNA nucleotides A, G, U, C are DNA nucleotides
questions.correct_answer: B. 2 and 3 are correct
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Codon

Three-nucleotide sequence in mRNA

Codon Functions

Specifies an amino acid sequence in proteins.

Start codon (AUG): Signals the initiation of protein synthesis.

Stop codons(UAA, UAG, and UGA): Signals termination of protein synthesis

Total Codons

64 (4 nucleotides, each position can be A, U, G, or C)

DNA Nucleotides

A, G, T, C   (Options A, C, D ruled out)

RNA Nucleotides

A, G, U (replaces T), C  (Options A, C, D ruled out)

Amino Acid Codons

61 codons encode 20 amino acids

Reading Frame

mRNA sequence read from start codon to stop codon (Open Reading Frame)

questions.text: The wobble phenomenon in tRNA decoding is primarily due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Inosine forming non-standard base pairs at the third codon position.

options.label: B
options.text: The exact matching of all three nucleotides between codon and anticodon.

options.label: C
options.text: Single tRNA binds only to one specific codon.

options.label: D
options.text: The rigid Watson-Crick base pairing at the third position of the codon.

questions.correct_answer: A. Inosine forming non-standard base pairs at the third codon position.
questions.explanation:
Codon Position

Standard Base Pairing

Wobble Pairing

Example

1st and 2nd

Watson-Crick rules

(Option D ruled out)

Strict

AGA and AGG code for Arginine.

3rd

Non-standard pairing

Flexible

AGA/AGG with UCU, GGU/GGC/GGA with CCI

questions.text: In the context of genetic code degeneracy, which of the following accurately describes its impact on protein synthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Single codon specifies one amino acid.

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple codons can code for the same amino acid.

options.label: C
options.text: Flexibility occurs at the 2nd codon position.

options.label: D
options.text: Inosine in mRNA contributes to the flexibility in pairing.

questions.correct_answer: B. Multiple codons can code for the same amino acid.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary mechanisms and applications of RNA interference (RNAi)?

options.label: A
options.text: Degradation of mRNA; used for gene manipulation and therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: Enhancement of mRNA synthesis; used for genetic modifications.

options.label: C
options.text: Conversion of mRNA to DNA; used for protein structure studies.

options.label: D
options.text: Stabilisation of mRNA; used for treating infections.

questions.correct_answer: A. Degradation of mRNA; used for gene manipulation and therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old student is reviewing the roles of small RNAs in cellular processes. She learns about small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) and small interfering RNAs (siRNAs). Which of the following statements about snRNAs and/or siRNAs is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both snRNAs and siRNAs are involved in the degradation of mRNA.

options.label: B
options.text: snRNAs form complexes with the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).

options.label: C
options.text: snRNAs are primarily involved in mRNA splicing and are located in the nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: snRNAs are typically found in the cytoplasm, while siRNAs are found in the nucleus.

questions.correct_answer: C. snRNAs are primarily involved in mRNA splicing and are located in the nucleus.
questions.explanation:
Feature

snRNAs

siRNAs

Main Function

RNA processing

Gene regulation

Location

(Option C)

(Option D ruled out)

Nucleus

Cytoplasm

Involvement

(Option A ruled out)

 

mRNA splicing, transcription elongation

mRNA degradation

Specific Types

U1, U2, U4, U5, U6 (splicing); U7 (histone mRNAs); 7SK (transcription)

Typically 21-25 nucleotides long

Role in mRNA

Removes introns, generates correct 3' ends of histone mRNAs

Silences gene expression

Source

Endogenous snRNAs

Endogenous/exogenous dsRNAs processed into siRNAs

Processing Mechanism

Forms complexes with proteins (snRNPs) for splicing

Processed by Dicer enzyme into siRNA duplexes

Associated Complex

(Option B ruled out)

Small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs)

RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC)

Length

Varies; generally 100-300 nucleotides

21-25 nucleotides

Stability

Generally stable, involved in essential RNA processes

Short-lived, rapidly degrades target mRNA

Biogenesis

Transcribed by RNA polymerase II or III

Derived from longer dsRNA precursors

Function in Disease

Defects can lead to splicing disorders (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy)

Utilized in RNAi therapies for gene silencing (e.g., in cancer)

Example Applications

Studying splicing mechanisms, understanding transcription regulation

Therapeutic gene silencing, functional genomics studies

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the synthesis of mRNA?

options.label: A
options.text: Introns are the coding sequence in a mRNA

options.label: B
options.text: 7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA

options.label: C
options.text: Process of splicing occurs in the cytoplasm

options.label: D
options.text: Heteronuclear RNA is not a functional mRNA

questions.correct_answer: D. Heteronuclear RNA is not a functional mRNA

questions.text: Which of the following steps in the process of tRNA synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm?

options.label: A
options.text: Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages giving rise to pseudouridine

options.label: C
options.text: Fourth post-transcriptional modification of random methylation

options.label: D
options.text: Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases attach the amino acid

questions.correct_answer: D. Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases attach the amino acid

questions.text: Which statement best describes the wobble hypothesis in relation to tRNA's function?

options.label: A
options.text: Allows multiple tRNAs to bind to a single codon.

options.label: B
options.text: Explains tRNA's ability to bind to any codon with perfect complementarity.

options.label: C
options.text: Single tRNA recognizes multiple codons due to flexible base pairing.

options.label: D
options.text: Accounts for varying tRNA lengths matching different mRNA sequences.

questions.correct_answer: C. Single tRNA recognizes multiple codons due to flexible base pairing.
questions.explanation:
Component

Description

Function

Amino Acid Acceptor Arm

Located at the 3' end, ending in CCA, which is added post-transcriptionally. The amino acid is attached to the 3′-OH group of the A moiety.

Charging: Amino acids are attached to the tRNA by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases for protein synthesis.

D Arm

Contains dihydrouridine, a modified base. Contributes to the overall structure and recognition of tRNA by its corresponding aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.

Recognition: Ensures correct aminoacylation by interacting with aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.

TψC Arm

Named for its ribothymidine (T), pseudouridine (ψ), and cytidine (C) content. Involved in binding tRNA to the ribosome.

Binding: Positions tRNA correctly at the ribosome for protein synthesis.

Anticodon Loop

Opposite the amino acid acceptor arm, contains a sequence of three nucleotides (anticodon) complementary to the codon on mRNA.
 

Wobble phenomenon

  • Third nucleotide pair formation is non-specific (more than one codon coding for a single amino acid)

(Or)

  • Reduced stringency when the third nucleotide pair is formed between codon and anti-codon.

(Or)

  • When tRNA is written in 5’, 3’ direction, the first nucleotide of the anticodon of tRNA is not specific

Degeneracy

More than one codon coding for a single amino acid because of the wobble phenomenon.

Codon Recognition: Ensures the correct amino acid is added to the polypeptide chain during translation.

Variable Arm

Located between the TψC arm and the anticodon loop. Its length varies among different tRNA species and contributes to the tertiary structure of tRNA.

Structural Flexibility: Aids in interactions with the ribosome and other translation factors.

questions.text: Which of the following types of rRNA is associated with the 40S ribosomal subunit in eukaryotic cells?
questions.correct_answer: B. 18S rRNA
questions.explanation:
Type of RNA

Characteristics

Function

mRNA (messenger RNA)
  • Single-stranded
  • Varies in length depending on the encoded protein
  • Contains exons and introns (in eukaryotes)
  • Carries genetic information from DNA to the ribosome
  • Encodes the amino acid sequence of proteins
  • Undergoes processing such as capping, polyadenylation, and splicing in eukaryotes

tRNA (transfer RNA)
  • Small, typically 73-93 nucleotides
  • Cloverleaf structure
  • Contains an anticodon and an amino acid attachment site
  • Transfers specific amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis
  • Recognizes codons on mRNA through its anticodon region
  • Plays a critical role in translating the genetic code into protein

rRNA (ribosomal RNA)
  • Forms the core of ribosome's structure
  • Eukaryotic ribosomes: 18S (40S subunit), 5.8S, 28S, 5S (components of the 60S subunit)
  • Prokaryotic ribosomes: 16S, 23S, 5S
  • Major structural and functional components of ribosomes
  • Catalyzes peptide bond formation during protein synthesis

snRNA (small nuclear RNA)
  • Small, usually less than 200 nucleotides
  • Found in the nucleus
  • Component of the spliceosome
  • Involved in the processing of pre-mRNA in eukaryotes
  • Essential for splicing introns from pre-mRNA

miRNA (microRNA)
  • Small, approximately 22 nucleotides
  • Single-stranded
  • Forms hairpin structures
  • Regulates gene expression post-transcriptionally
  • Binds to complementary sequences on target mRNAs, resulting in translational repression or mRNA degradation
  • Plays a role in various biological processes including development, differentiation, and apoptosis

siRNA (small interfering RNA)
  • Short, double-stranded RNA, about 20-25 nucleotides
  • Originates from longer double-stranded RNA
  • Involved in the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway
  • Mediates the degradation of specific mRNAs
  • Used experimentally to silence gene expression
